metadata.name: DriverQuery.EXE Execution
metadata.comment: Detect usage of the "driverquery" utility. Which can be used to perform reconnaissance on installed drivers

batch.sql: SELECT * FROM process_activity WHERE time BETWEEN CURRENT_TIMESTAMP() - INTERVAL 24 HOUR AND CURRENT_TIMESTAMP() AND (activity_id = 1 AND endswith(lower(process.name), lower('driverquery.exe')) AND lower(process.file.name) = lower('drvqry.exe') AND NOT ((endswith(lower(process.parent_process.name), lower('\\\\cscript.exe')) OR endswith(lower(process.parent_process.name), lower('\\\\mshta.exe')) OR endswith(lower(process.parent_process.name), lower('\\\\regsvr32.exe')) OR endswith(lower(process.parent_process.name), lower('\\\\rundll32.exe')) OR endswith(lower(process.parent_process.name), lower('\\\\wscript.exe'))) AND (contains(lower(process.parent_process.name), lower('\\\\appdata\\\\local\\\\')) OR contains(lower(process.parent_process.name), lower('\\\\users\\\\public\\\\')) OR contains(lower(process.parent_process.name), lower('\\\\windows\\\\temp\\\\')))))

output.summary: Detect usage of the "driverquery" utility. Which can be used to perform reconnaissance on installed drivers

metadata.objective: False positive: Legitimate use by third party tools in order to investigate installed drivers References: https://thedfirreport.com/2023/01/09/unwrapping-ursnifs-gifts/, https://www.vmray.com/cyber-security-blog/analyzing-ursnif-behavior-malware-sandbox/, https://www.fireeye.com/blog/threat-research/2020/01/saigon-mysterious-ursnif-fork.html
